questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office to check up. The patient feels well, aside from the occasional headache and frequent falls. The rest of the history is unremarkable. The patient has a past medical history of type II  diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 145/80 mmHg. Fundoscopy reveals thinning of the optic disc rim and asymmetry of the cup/disc ratio between the eyes. The rest of the neurological exam is within normal limits. A diagnosis of open-angle glaucoma is established. The patient asks the physician about topical pilocarpine that his brother has been using for the same condition. This medication will help treat open-angle glaucoma via which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Decreased secretion of aqueous humor from the ciliary epithelium
Ciliary muscle contraction and increased trabecular outflow
​Decreased aqueous secretion due to lack of HCO3–

questions.solution:
Topical pilocarpine is a cholinergic agonist that can be used to treat open-angle glaucoma (OAG).

Cholinergic agonists (e.g., pilocarpine, carbachol) lower the intraocular pressure (IOP) by causing muscarinic-induced contraction of the ciliary muscle, which facilitates aqueous outflow via the trabecular meshwork. They do not affect aqueous production. Pilocarpine is very effective at opening meshwork into the canal of Schlemm and can be used in acute angle-closure glaucoma.

Ciliary body spasm is a muscarinic cholinergic effect that can induce myopia and refraction due to iris and ciliary body contraction. The drug effect waxes and wanes between doses. Headaches can also occur from the iris and ciliary body contraction. The ocular side effects have decreased the utilization of these drugs, and they are not typically first-line medications used in OAG.  

Option Analysis

❌ Decreased secretion of aqueous humor from the ciliary epithelium:
Incorrect: Beta-blockers (e.g., timolol. betaxolol, and carvedilol) are an effective treatment option for glaucoma. It decreases the secretion of aqueous humor from the ciliary epithelium.  
❌ Increased aqueous humor uveoscleral outflow:
Incorrect: Prostaglandin analogs (e.g., latanoprost and bimatoprost) increase the outflow of aqueous humor by decreasing the resistance of flow through the uveoscleral pathway.  
✅ Ciliary muscle contraction and increased trabecular outflow:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ ​Decreased aqueous secretion due to lack of HCO3–:
Incorrect:  Carbonic anhydrase (CA) inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide, and brinzolamide) are effective treatment options for glaucoma. It works by inhibiting CA, which is found in the ciliary body epithelium, thus inhibiting aqueous humor formation due to lack of HCO3–.  
❌ Removal of water from eye:
Incorrect: Intravenous mannitol (diuretic) is also sometimes used to treat acute glaucoma. It dehydrates the vitreous humor and, therefore, lowers the intraocular pressure.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of bilateral eye pain, which has been ongoing for the past 2 weeks. The pain was initially described as a “sand in my eyes” feeling, but it has now progressed to sharp, stabbing pain. The patient previously used artificial tears, but now they provide minimal symptomatic relief. In addition, the patient has been experiencing dryness in the mouth and joint pain in the fingers. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 145/83 mmHg, and pulse is 77/min. There is bilateral conjunctival injection. The oral mucosal membranes are dry. A Shirmer test is performed and reveals decreased tear production. The patient is prescribed a medication that improves tear and saliva production. Several days later, the patient begins experiencing shortness of breath and wheezing. Which medication was she most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with dry eyes (due to decreased tear production), dry mouth, and joint pain. These findings are suggestive of Sjogren syndrome (SS), a chronic multisystem inflammatory disorder characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the lacrimal and salivary glands that results in dry eyes and mouth. This patient was most likely treated with systemic pilocarpine, a cholinomimetic that stimulates secretions from the lacrimal and salivary glands. Pilocarpine also acts on the bronchial smooth muscles, causing bronchospasm in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Cholinomimetics (e.g., bethanechol, carbachol, pilocarpine) have no absolute contraindications. However, since they cause bronchospasms, they should be avoided in individuals with COPD and asthma. Moreover, they increase gastric acid secretion and should be avoided in individuals with peptic ulcer disease.  

Option Analysis

✅ Pilocarpine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ipratropium:
Incorrect: Ipratropium is an anticholinergic medication used in the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Ipratropium is unlikely to exacerbate COPD symptoms.  
❌ Mirabegron:
Incorrect: Sympathomimetics such as mirabegron act on the β3-receptor to cause relaxation of the detrusor smooth muscle, which leads to increased bladder capacity. Mirabegron is used in the management of urinary incontinence, but has no role in increasing tear or saliva production. Moreover, it does cause chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation.  
❌ Miconazole:
Incorrect: Miconazole is an antifungal agent used to treat oral candidiasis. Although this patient has a dry mouth, there is no evidence of a fungal infection. Moreover, miconazole does not cause chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation.  
❌ Bethanechol:
Incorrect: Bethanechol is a cholinomimetic agent that can be administered to stimulate intestinal motility in patients with ileus or bladder contractility and emptying in patients with urinary retention. Bethanechol is not typically used in the production of tears and saliva. Therefore, it is unlikely this patient was prescribed bethanechol.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to his primary physician for evaluation of an “ear problem.” The patient is a retired mixed martial arts fighter and wants to know if there is anything that he can do to fix the appearance of his left ear. The patient reports he was punched in his left ear several years ago, and he was left with the deformity demonstrated in the image below. This patient’s condition was likely the result of hematoma accumulation in which of the following anatomic structures?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with cauliflower ear, or boxer’s ear, which results from accumulation of blood in the subperichondrial space. This condition is most often the result of a direct blow to the external ear – particularly the components containing cartilage, such as the helix, the antihelix, the concha, tragus, and antitragus.

The skin overlying the cartilaginous components of the ear is tightly adherent to the underlying perichondrium, which subsequently supplies nutrients to the cartilage below. When trauma occurs to the cartilaginous components of the external ear, blood can accumulate between the perichondrium and cartilage. Without proper drainage, the hematoma acts as a mechanical barrier between the cartilage and its perichondrial blood supply, ultimately resulting in necrosis, fibrosis and neocartilage formation. The result is a cosmetically deformed external ear, known as cauliflower ear.  

Option Analysis

✅ Subperichondrial space:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ External acoustic meatus  :
Incorrect: The external acoustic meatus is a short, curved tube that burrows through the temporal bone and ends at the tympanic membrane. The external acoustic meatus is not involved in the development of cauliflower ear.  
❌ Ear lobule  :
Incorrect: The ear lobule or lobe is the fleshy portion of the auricle. This component of external ear anatomy is made up of skin and fat and hence does not contribute to the formation of cauliflower ear given it is devoid of cartilage.  
❌ Tympanic membrane  :
Incorrect: The tympanic membrane, also called the eardrum, is a thin, translucent membrane that separates the external ear from the middle ear. It is responsible for transmitting vibrations to the bones of the inner ear. The tympanic membrane is not involved in the development of cauliflower ear.  
❌ The epitympanic recess  :
Incorrect: The roof of the middle ear is also called the epitympanic recess. The epitympanic recess is not involved in the development of cauliflower ear.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of left ear pain and ringing. The patient reports an insidious onset of her symptoms four to five days ago. The patient states, “I tried listening to classical music yesterday to calm my nerves, and I experienced a shooting pain in my left ear.” The patient is otherwise healthy, and her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates diminished sensation in the left ear, left sided facial droop, and inability to wrinkle the left forehead. Which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this patient’s otologic symptomatology?
questions.solution:
Bell palsy, or facial nerve paralysis, is a common cause of hyperacusis – a hearing disorder characterized by increased sensitivity to high frequency and high volume sounds. The stapedius muscle contracts in response to loud noise, thus dampening the vibrations of the ossicles and protecting the ear.

Paralysis of the facial nerve (CN VII) results in the inability of the stapedius to contract and causes sounds to be abnormally loud on the affected side.

Hyperacusis can be an incredibly debilitating condition, most commonly caused by prolonged exposure to high decibel sounds. Other common conditions associated with this condition include Bell Palsy or Meniere disease. Symptoms include pain in the affected ear when exposed to noise.  

Option Analysis

✅ Stapedius muscle  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Incus  :
Incorrect: The incus represents the anvil-shaped bone in the middle ear, which transmits vibrations between the malleus and stapes. It is not the primary anatomic site of pathology in patients with hyperacusis.  
❌ Malleus  :
Incorrect: The malleus is a hammer-shaped small bone or ossicle of the middle ear which connects to the incus and is attached to the inner surface of the tympanic membrane. It is not the primary anatomic site of pathology in patients with hyperacusis.  
❌ CN V  :
Incorrect: The facial nerve, not the trigeminal nerve, is implicated in the pathogenesis of hyperacusis.    
❌ Greater petrosal nerve  :
Incorrect: The greater petrosal nerve branches from the facial nerve to form a chain of nerves that innervate the lacrimal gland. This nerve is not implicated in patients with hyperacusis.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician for evaluation of hearing loss. The patient's mother states, “He never comes when he is called; I am not even sure if he knows his name.” The patient was born full term via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. Medical history is notable for an episode of croup when he was 6-months-old and a femoral fracture when he was 2-years-old, which occurred after the patient fell off a couch and landed on the floor. The patient’s father has a history of multiple fractures, some of which occurred after falling from standing height. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 98/65 mmHg, and pulse is 70/min. Otoscopic evaluation is within normal limits. When a tuning fork is struck, the patient has an improved sense of hearing when the fork is placed against the mastoid process, when compared to directly over the ear. The patient's ocular examination is notable for the following finding:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons    

This patient’s disease process reflects damage to which of the following anatomic structures?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of hearing loss and has a history suspicious for osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), given his femoral fracture and blue sclera on physical examination. Patients with OI are at risk for developing hearing loss.  

Hearing loss is broadly categorized into conductive, sensorineural, and mixed hearing loss. Conductive hearing loss reflects any disease process that affects the transmission of sound from the outside world to the inner ear. Anatomic structures affected in conductive hearing loss include the auricle, external auditory canal, tympanic membrane, and ossicles. Common etiologies include cerumen impaction, tympanic membrane perforation, otosclerosis, otitis media/externa, and cholesteatomas.  

In contrast, sensorineural hearing loss reflects any disease process that affects the transmission of neuronal input to the central nervous via damage to the cochlea or auditory nerve. Common etiologies include presbycusis, noise-induced hearing loss, schwannomas, and Meniere disease. Other etiologies include ototoxic medications (e.g. aminoglycosides), congenital viral infections, congenital long QT syndrome, and Alport syndrome.   

Finally, some conditions such as osteogenesis imperfecta can present with mixed hearing loss, though patients tend to have predominantly one or the other. The conductive hearing loss in OI occurs due to malformation, dislocation, or fracture of the ossicles. The sensorineural hearing loss is hypothesized to occur secondary to cochlear hair cell atrophy or bone formation within the cochlea. The patient in this vignette has OI with predominantly conductive hearing loss, since the Rinne test demonstrates bone conduction greater than air conduction.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ossicles :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Auditory nerve :
Incorrect: Damage to the auditory nerve may occur through ischemia or mass effect from a malignancy or hematoma, which would result in sensorineural hearing loss. In contrast, this patient’s Rinne test demonstrates bone conduction greater than air conduction, which is more concerning for conductive hearing loss.
❌ Ear canal  :
Incorrect: Cerumen impaction, debris, malignancy, and congenital malformations can contribute to conductive hearing loss by impairing sound traveling through the external auditory canal. However, this patient’s history of a femoral fracture after a minor fall and presence of blue sclera on physical examination are concerning for osteogenesis imperfecta. Osteogenesis imperfecta can affect the middle ear bones and cochlea, but does not typically affect the ear canal.
❌ Tympanic membrane :
Incorrect: Damage to the tympanic membrane may occur through vascular malformations, direct trauma, barotrauma, or inner ear infections. This structure is not typically damaged in patients with osteogenesis imperfecta. 
❌ Cochlea :
Incorrect: The cochlea is an inner ear structure responsible for producing nerve impulses in response to sound vibrations. Atrophy of cochlear hair cells and formation of abnormal bone within the cochlear have been proposed as mechanisms to explain the sensorineural hearing loss experienced by patients with osteogenesis imperfecta. However, this patient’s Rinne test demonstrates bone conduction greater than air conduction, which is more concerning for conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of left ear pain and facial swelling. The patient reports swelling to the left face over the past week and is worried something is “wrong with her ear.” The patient reports pain primarily at the angle of the jaw and the majority of the pinna. The patient undergoes a CT-scan of the face which demonstrates findings consistent with left sided-parotitis. Which of the nerves is most likely to be implicated as the source of the pain based on this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Referred ear pain, or secondary otalgia is often indicative of pathology involving structures in close proximity to the ear, based on the cutaneous innervation of the ear. In the context of parotitis, the referred ear pain is most likely subsequent to inflammation of the great auricular nerve, which supplies both the skin over the parotid gland, as well as the majority of the pinna and the angle of the jaw. Additional examples of secondary otalgia include temporomandibular joint disorder, Bell palsy, sinusitis, oropharyngeal infections, as well as auricular lymphadenopathy or lymphadenitis. A detailed anatomic understanding of the cutaneous innervation of the ear can help to clinically predict an underlying secondary otalgia.  



Option Analysis

✅ Great auricular nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lesser occipital nerve  :
Incorrect: The lesser occipital nerve supplies the posterolateral scalp, supra auricular scalp, and superior pinna. The lesser occipital nerve is not the most likely source of pain.  
❌ Auriculotemporal nerve  :
Incorrect: The auriculotemporal nerve supplies the temporal scalp, the external auditory meatus, preauricular area and tragus, and the temporomandibular joint. The auriculotemporal nerve is not the most likely source of pain.  
❌ CN X  :
Incorrect: In the context of ear anatomy, the vagus nerve supplies the lateral surface of the tympanic membrane, external acoustic meatus, and the concha. This nerve is not the most likely source of pain.    
❌ CN IX  :
Incorrect: In the context of ear anatomy, CN IX supplies the mastoid air cells, middle ear, and medial surface of the tympanic membrane. This nerve is not the most likely source of pain.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of persistent left ear fullness. The patient endorses worsening fullness and pain in his left ear for six to eight weeks and states his ear feels “plugged.” During this time, the patient also endorses intermittent epistaxis from the left nostril. He and his family are originally from Hong Kong, though he immigrated to the United States many years ago. He has a twenty-pack-year smoking history. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a bulging left tympanic membrane with serous effusion and auricular lymphadenopathy. Which of the following best describes the anatomic etiology for this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Bony overgrowth involving the footplate of the stapes

questions.solution:
This patient presents with several features consistent with underlying nasopharyngeal carcinoma including South Chinese descent, epistaxis, serous otitis media, and associated lymphadenopathy. The primary cause of serous otitis media secondary to nasopharyngeal carcinoma is eustachian tube obstruction.

The eustachian tube is a cavity that connects the throat to the middle ear and helps with pressure regulation, protection of the middle ear, and mucociliary clearance. Obstructive etiologies often prohibit these mechanisms and produce symptoms that include ear fullness or pressure, hearing loss, and tinnitus. Patients often complain of their ears feeling “plugged.”

Obstructive etiologies are generally those that involve inflammation or mass effect. Common bilateral causes include inflammatory etiologies such as rhinosinusitis, sinusitis, and allergic rhinitis, or adenoid hypertrophy. Unilateral eustachian tube obstruction raises concern for mass effect from a compressive tumor, such as nasopharyngeal carcinoma.  

Option Analysis

✅ Eustachian tube obstruction  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tympanic membrane perforation  :
Incorrect: Tympanic membrane perforation may occur in individuals exposed to loud noises (e.g., gunshots, explosions). However, this patient’s tympanic membrane is intact without evidence of perforation.  
❌ Great auricular nerve entrapment  :
Incorrect: Parotitis may result in referred ear pain, or secondary otalgia, due to impingement of the great auricular nerve. This patient does not have evidence of parotis (e.g. left pre-auricular edema, erythema, pain).  
❌ Impaired reabsorption of endolymphatic fluid  :
Incorrect: Meniere disease is characterized by impaired reabsorption and accumulation of endolymphatic fluid within the cochlea and vestibular organs. The condition typically presents with fluctuating unilateral hearing loss associated with tinnitus and vertigo.    
❌ Bony overgrowth involving the footplate of the stapes  :
Incorrect: Otosclerosis is characterized by bony remodeling and overgrowth of the middle ear ossicles. The footplate of the stapes is most commonly affected. The condition presents with low-frequency conductive hearing loss.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman goes to her primary care physician because of progressive right sided hearing loss over the past three months. The patient states, “I cannot hear conversations out of this ear anymore; it feels like my ear is all plugged up.” She also has had tinnitus and balance issues during this time period. During the physical exam, the physician strikes a tuning fork and places it on the patient’s forehead. The abnormal finding from this test prompts the physician to order MRI imaging of the brain, which reveals the following:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following combinations of Weber and Rinne test results are most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result  Lateralization to the left ear  Air conduction greater than bone conduction
Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result  Lateralization to the left ear Bone conduction greater than air conduction
Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result Lateralization to the right ear Air conduction greater than bone conduction
Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result Lateralization to the right earBone conduction greater than air conduction
Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result  No lateralization will be presentAir conduction greater than bone conduction

questions.solution:
This patient’s history and MRI findings are consistent with those of an acoustic neuroma (also termed vestibular schwannoma). Vestibular schwannomas can result in sensorineural hearing loss, which on Weber testing would demonstrate lateralization of sound to the unaffected ear.   

Two tests, the Weber test and Rinne test, can help determine if a patient has conductive or sensorineural hearing loss. The Weber test is performed by placing a struck tuning fork on the bridge of the forehead, and in a healthy individual, there would be no lateralization of sound. With unilateral conductive hearing loss, sound lateralizes to the affected ear, whereas with sensorineural hearing loss, sound lateralizes to the normal ear.  

The Rinne test is performed by placing the base of a struck tuning fork on the mastoid bone until the patient no longer hears sound. Next, the fork is moved beside the ear and the patient is asked if they can still hear sound. In a normal test, air conduction is greater than bone conduction. However, in patients with conductive hearing loss, bone conduction is greater than air conduction. Unfortunately, the Rinne test cannot differentiate between healthy individuals and those with sensorineural hearing loss, as both present with air conduction greater than bone conduction.  

Option Analysis

✅   Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result  Lateralization to the left ear  Air conduction greater than bone conduction :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result  Lateralization to the left ear Bone conduction greater than air conduction:
Incorrect: This patient's right ear hearing loss is primarily sensorineural, given the findings of a vestibular schwannoma (also termed acoustic neuroma) on MRI. A Weber test will demonstrate lateralization of sound to the unaffected (left) ear. However, in sensorineural hearing loss, the Rinne test will reveal air conduction that is greater than bone conduction.
❌   Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result Lateralization to the right ear Air conduction greater than bone conduction:
Incorrect: This patient's right ear hearing loss is primarily sensorineural, given the findings of a vestibular schwannoma (also termed acoustic neuroma) on MRI. With sensorineural hearing loss, a Weber test will demonstrate sound lateralization to the unaffected (left) ear.
❌   Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result Lateralization to the right earBone conduction greater than air conduction:
Incorrect: A Rinne test revealing bone conduction greater than air conduction is suggestive of conductive hearing loss. The Weber test demonstrates lateralization of sound to the right ear. In combination, these findings are suggestive of right-sided conductive hearing loss. In contrast, this patient has a right vestibular schwannoma, which would more likely cause sensorineural hearing loss.
❌   Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result  No lateralization will be presentAir conduction greater than bone conduction:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the Weber and Rinne test findings in a healthy individual. In contrast, this patient has a right-sided vestibular schwannoma, which would cause sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider for evaluation of ear drainage. The patient has had intermittent, foul-smelling drainage coming from the left ear over the past two weeks. In addition, she has noticed difficulty hearing out of the left ear. On physical exam, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 118/77 mmHg, and pulse is 64/min. An otoscopic evaluation of the affected ear is performed and demonstrates the following:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons   

Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient's clinical presentation?

choices.text: Benign trabecular bone and fibrofatty marrow

questions.solution:
This patient has left ear drainage, hearing loss, and an otoscopic examination that demonstrates collection of keratin debris and a retraction pocket in the tympanic membrane. These findings are suggestive of a cholesteatoma, which is a benign lesion caused by overgrowth of keratinized squamous epithelium.  

Cholesteatoma refers to an abnormal accumulation of squamous epithelium that most commonly develops behind the tympanic membrane. This condition has both congenital and acquired forms, with the latter being more common. Congenital cholesteatomas are present at birth and are a result of embryonic nests of squamous cells that remain in the middle ear after birth. Acquired cholesteatomas often occur due to eustachian tube dysfunction and subsequent formation of a retraction pocket that allows desquamating skin cells to accumulate into a slowly expanding mass.  

Clinically, cholesteatomas present with painless ear drainage, which may be foul-smelling, and conductive hearing loss. Otoscopic evaluation will often demonstrate retraction of the tympanic membrane around ossicles as well as a mass behind the tympanic membrane. If left untreated, these lesions can erode the ossicles or mastoid bone.  

Option Analysis

✅ Accumulation of keratinized squamous epithelium:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Infiltrating polygonal squamous cells :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the histopathology of squamous cell cancer of the ear, which is overall a rare neoplasm. Physical examination could also demonstrate associated lymphadenopathy, nerve palsy, and significant ear pain. 
❌ Benign trabecular bone and fibrofatty marrow:
Incorrect: External auditory osteomas are a rare type of tumor composed of benign bone and marrow tissue. Osteomas typically present as a smooth mass growing from the walls of the ear canal.   
❌ Growth of malignant melanocytes :
Incorrect: Melanoma presents as an area of skin characterized by irregular borders, variations in color (e.g., brown, black, tan), and asymmetry. It most often affects sun-exposed areas of skin. In contrast, melanoma of the tympanic membrane would be an extremely rare condition.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the clinic due to difficulty hearing for the past 2 months. He describes difficulty hearing mainly on the left side, and he notes a constant “whoosh” sound in the same ear. The patient reports feeling unsteady lately but denies any dizziness or spinning sensations. Medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia and hypertension. Medications include furosemide and lovastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows that the patient does not respond when the physician whispers in the left ear. A tuning fork placed on the mastoid bone shows that air conduction is greater than bone conduction bilaterally. When the fork is placed on the top of the head, the sound localizes to the right ear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with unilateral progressive hearing loss, imbalance, and tinnitus. The results of his Rinne test showed the air conduction > bone conduction, indicating normal results and no conductive hearing loss. His Weber test results showed that the noise lateralized to the unaffected ear, confirming sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear. These signs and symptoms are indicative of a left-sided acoustic neuroma (also known as a vestibular schwannoma).  

Acoustic neuromas, also known as vestibular schwannoma, are Schwann cell-derived tumors that often arise from the vestibular portion of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). The incidence is similar in men and women, and the median age at diagnosis is approximately 50 years. Tumors are usually unilateral, but acoustic neuromas can occur bilaterally in patients with neurofibromatosis type 2. Common presenting symptoms include progressive hearing loss, tinnitus, and unsteadiness while walking. True spinning vertigo is uncommon, because these slow-growing tumors cause gradual asymmetries, which allows the vestibular system to compensate on the unaffected side. Diagnosis can be made with imaging, and treatment involves resection of the tumor.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cholesteatoma :
Incorrect: Cholesteatomas are abnormal, noncancerous desquamated keratin debris that can develop within the middle ear space behind the eardrum. A cholesteatoma may be present at birth, but most commonly, it is caused by repeated middle ear infections. It may erode ossicles and mastoid air cells leading to conductive hearing loss. A cholesteatoma would not cause vestibular symptoms, tinnitus or sensorineural hearing loss.  
❌ Ménière disease:
Incorrect: Ménière disease, also known as idiopathic endolymphatic hydrops, is caused by increased hydraulic pressure within the inner ear endolymphatic system. Patients often present with vertigo, tinnitus, ear fullness or pain, and sensorineural hearing loss. Episodes are spontaneous and characterized by vertigo, which can last 20 minutes to 12 hours. Although some of this patient’s symptoms overlap with Ménière disease, his symptoms are constant, and he describes unsteadiness rather than true vertigo.   
❌ Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo  :
Incorrect: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) refers to the episodic sensation of vertigo caused by calcium debris within the semicircular canals. Episodes are typically provoked by head rotation and position changes. In contrast to other causes of vertigo, hearing loss and other neurologic symptoms are not seen.   
✅ Acoustic neuroma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Medication side effect:
Incorrect: Furosemide, a loop diuretic, can cause ototoxicity leading to temporary or permanent hearing loss. This side effect mainly depends on the dose and rate of administration; ototoxicity may be seen when the dose exceeds 240 mg per hour. Therefore, it is more likely to occur in an inpatient setting and in patients with chronic kidney disease, rather than with oral administration. Also, vestibular symptoms are not expected.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man goes to his primary care physician for evaluation of hearing loss. The patient has had worsening hearing loss out of the right ear for the past six to nine months. He has also been experiencing intermittent ringing in the affected ear. Family history is notable for similar symptoms in his father, who developed progressive hearing loss starting at the age of 35. On physical exam, temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 147/88 mmHg, and pulse is 73/min. Otoscopy of the patient's right tympanic membrane demonstrates the finding below. Audiometric testing demonstrates low-frequency hearing loss in the right ear.



  Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons 

Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Bony overgrowth involving the footplate of the stapes
Growth of benign trabecular bone and fibrofatty marrow

questions.solution:
This patient has progressive conductive, low-frequency hearing loss with a normal appearing tympanic membrane. Given these findings and his family history, he most likely has otosclerosis.

Otosclerosis is a relatively common type of hearing loss affecting the adult population. The underlying pathophysiology of the disease is thought to be due to bony remodeling of the middle ear ossicles, and in particular, the footplate of the stapes. This process leads to impaired conduction of sound; the bony overgrowth impairs movement of the stapes and reduces transmission of sound from the tympanic membrane to the cochlea.

The condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern and has incomplete penetrance. Approximately 60% of adults with otosclerosis report having a family history of the condition.

Diagnosis is primarily clinical, with the majority of patients presenting with progressive conductive, low-frequency hearing loss, tinnitus, or dizziness. Otoscopic evaluations are normal in the majority of affected individuals. The Rinne test will demonstrate bone conduction greater than air condition. The Weber test will localize to the affected ear. CT imaging will often demonstrate thickening of the stapes, which confirms the diagnosis.    

Option Analysis

✅ Bony overgrowth involving the footplate of the stapes:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Accumulation of keratinized squamous epithelium:
Incorrect: Cholesteatomas are caused by the accumulation of keratinized squamous epithelium, most commonly in the middle ear. In contrast, this patient’s physical examination reveals a normal right ear tympanic membrane.
❌ Fracture of middle ear ossicles:
Incorrect: Osteogenesis imperfecta is a hereditary condition characterized by decreased synthesis of type I collagen. The condition results in ossicles that are prone to malformation, dislocation, and fracture. However, patients with osteogenesis imperfecta typically would not have primarily a low frequency hearing loss and would often have other findings, such as blue sclera and a history of multiple bone fractures.
❌ Growth of benign trabecular bone and fibrofatty marrow:
Incorrect: External auditory osteomas are a rare type of tumor composed of benign bone and marrow tissue. Osteomas typically present as a smooth mass growing from the walls of the ear canal. No such findings were observed on this patient’s physical exam.  
❌ Growth of a hypervascular neoplasm:
Incorrect: Jugulotympanic paragangliomas are highly vascular, typically benign neuroendocrine tumors that arise either from the promontory of the middle ear or the adventitia of the dome of the jugular bulb. This condition can cause progressive conductive hearing loss. However, these tumors are extremely rare. Furthermore, this patient has a family history of progressive hearing loss, which raises concerns for a hereditary condition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to feeling unbalanced and difficulty hearing. Her symptoms began gradually 2 months ago and have worsened since then. She describes episodes of a sensation that she is swaying, and she has difficulty maintaining her balance; the episodes last for a few hours. She also complains of constant buzzing sounds and mild pain in her left ear. Her symptoms seem to fluctuate throughout the day without a specific pattern. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows that rotation of the head does not provoke her symptoms. Audiometry reveals loss of low frequency sounds on the left ear. This patient’s presentation can be explained by which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Post-viral inflammation of the cranial nerve
Calcium debris within the semicircular canals

questions.solution:
This patient, who presents with hearing loss, tinnitus, ear pain, and vertigo, most likely has Ménière disease. 

Ménière disease, also known as idiopathic endolymphatic hydrops, is a condition that affects the inner ear. Endolymphatic hydrops refers to increased hydraulic pressure within the inner ear endolymphatic system. The excess pressure accumulation manifests as episodic hearing loss, vertigo, tinnitus, and ear pain or fullness sensation. The episodic attacks seen in Ménière disease typically lasts 20 minutes to 12 hours and symptoms wax and wane as the endolymphatic pressure rises and falls. The sensorineural hearing loss typically progresses, and may result in permanent hearing loss within 8 to 10 years.  

Diagnosis is made by fulfilling the following criteria:  
  •  2 or more spontaneous episodes of vertigo, lasting 20 minutes to 12 hours 
  •  Audiometry showing low- to mid-frequency sensorineural hearing loss in the affected ear 
  •  Waxing and waning aural symptoms (reduced or distorted hearing, tinnitus, or fullness) in the affected ear 
  •  Symptoms not explained by another vestibular diagnosis 

Option Analysis

❌ Post-viral inflammation of the cranial nerve:
Incorrect: Labyrinthitis, or vestibular neuritis, is an inflammation of the inner ear that results in vertigo, hearing loss or ringing in the ears. It is thought to be a viral or post-viral inflammatory disorder that leads to inflammation of the vestibular portion of the eighth cranial nerve. Patients often present with severe vertigo and possibly hearing loss and tinnitus. It typically occurs as an acute attack that lasts for days. This patient’s presentation and duration of symptoms favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Endolymphatic hydrops:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Autoimmune demyelination:
Incorrect: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system that damages the insulating covers of nerve cells. This damage disrupts neural transmission, resulting in a range of signs and symptoms, including physical, mental, and sometimes psychiatric problems. Patients may present with double vision, monocular blindness, muscle weakness, or sensory deficits. Although MS can present with similar symptoms as seen in this patient, the absence of other signs favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Perilymphatic fistula:
Incorrect: Perilymphatic fistula is a complication of head injury, barotrauma, or heavy lifting in which a fistula develops at the otic capsule. The fistula leads to pressure changes and altered signaling of the macular and cupular receptors. It is characterized by episodic vertigo and/or hearing loss provoked by sneezing, lifting, straining, coughing, and loud sounds.  
❌ Calcium debris within the semicircular canals :
Incorrect: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) refers to episodic vertigo sensation caused by calcium debris within the semicircular canals. Episodes typically provoked by head rotation and position changes. In contrast to other causes of vertigo, hearing and other neurologic symptoms are not seen.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of dizziness and hearing loss. The patient has had multiple episodes of dizziness lasting between 20 minutes to several hours. These episodes are associated with ringing in the left ear. The patient states, “These episodes are so debilitating I have to lie in bed until they are over. Sometimes the spinning sensation is so intense that I vomit.” Past medical history is noncontributory. She has not had any recent bacterial or viral infections. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination reveals no significant findings. Audiometric testing demonstrates low-mid frequency hearing loss in the left ear. Hearing in the right ear is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with episodes of vertigo, tinnitus, and low-mid frequency hearing loss. These findings are most consistent with Meniere disease.

Meniere disease is an inner ear disorder characterized by episodic attacks of vertigo, tinnitus, ear fullness, and hearing loss. Individual episodes can last anywhere from twenty minutes to 24 hours. The disease typically occurs in adults between the ages of 30 and 60. Meniere disease arises due to impaired reabsorption of endolymph fluid. Overtime, the fluid accumulates and causes distention of the semicircular canals; this phenomenon is termed endolymphatic hydrops.

Ultimately, these changes impair proper signaling through the labyrinthine system, causing disequilibrium, vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, as well as a sensation of ear fullness. Meniere disease is primarily a clinical diagnosis. Patients should also undergo audiometric testing to evaluate for low-mid frequency sensorineural hearing loss.

Treatment of Meniere disease aims to decrease the volume of the endolymphatic fluid. This can be done by limiting the intake of salt, caffeine, alcohol, and nicotine. If symptoms persist, diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide, acetazolamide) can be used. In severe, disabling cases, surgical options (e.g., labyrinthectomy, vestibular neurectomy) can be considered.    

Option Analysis

✅ Meniere disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Otosclerosis:
Incorrect: Otosclerosis is characterized by bony remodeling and overgrowth of the middle ear ossicles. The footplate of the stapes is most commonly affected. The condition presents with low-frequency conductive hearing loss. Otosclerosis would not typically present with the vertigo experienced by this patient.
❌ Labrynthitis:
Incorrect: Labrynthitis, also known as vestibular neuritis, is caused by inflammation of the inner ear structures. The condition manifests with intermittent vertigo, hearing loss, and loss of coordination. However, labrynthitis typically occurs in the setting of an active or recent upper respiratory tract infection.
❌ Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo:
Incorrect: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo arises from calcium crystals, known as otoconia or otoliths, that become dislodged from their usual position within the utricle. Over time, the otoliths migrate into the semicircular canals and can cause vertigo triggered by changes in position. However, the condition would not lead to hearing loss.
❌ Presbycusis:
Incorrect: Presbycusis is an age-related condition characterized by bilateral, high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. However, presbycusis would not account for the episodes of vertigo experienced by this patient.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of episodes of dizziness for the past month. The patient reports that the dizziness usually occurs when she gets up from bed, gets up from a seated position, or turns her head, and it lasts for approximately 30 seconds. During these episodes, she feels as though the room is spinning around her, which is accompanied by nausea. Medical history is significant for hypertension, which is treated with hydrochlorothiazide. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows right-beating and torsional nystagmus. Hearing is intact, and the rest of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?

choices.text: Inflammation of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII)
Excessive build-up of the endolymph fluid

questions.solution:
This patient, who presents with isolated complaints of vertigo that occurs mainly with head rotation and position changes, most likely has benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The diagnosis of BPPV can be confirmed by the Dix-Hallpike maneuver, in which the physician extends the patient's neck and turns it to one side while the patient is sitting, followed by rapidly placing them in a supine position so that their head hangs over the edge of the bed. On a positive test there will be nystagmus or vertigo.  

BPPV is one of the most common causes of peripheral vertigo; it is characterized by episodes of spinning sensation provoked by head rotation and position changes which last approximately 30 seconds. The condition is attributed to calcium debris within the semicircular canals, known as canalithiasis. This debris likely represents loose calcium carbonate crystals originating from the utricular sac. Under normal conditions, the semicircular canals detect angular head accelerations. Debris accumulation in the canal causes inappropriate movement of the endolymph with linear accelerations, creating a false sensation of spinning when the head shifts. While symptoms can be disabling, the disorder typically responds to treatment with particle-repositioning maneuvers (Epley maneuver) in the office upon diagnosis.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Depletion of body fluids:
Incorrect: This answer choice refers to orthostatic hypotension, which is diagnosed when a person's blood pressure falls upon standing or sitting. Although hydrochlorothiazide use does increase the risk for orthostatic hypotension, this phenomenon would not cause nystagmus or vertigo.   
❌ Arterial insufficiency:
Incorrect: Rotational vertebral artery syndrome refers to a phenomenon of symptomatic posterior circulation ischemia from the compression of the vertebral arteries by bony elements of the spine (usually at CI-C2) which occurs upon head rotation. Patients may present with recurrent syncope, vertigo, nystagmus, ataxia, diplopia, nausea, dysarthria, or dysphagia. Although some of this patient’s symptoms overlap with rotational vertebral artery syndrome, standing would not cause the symptoms.   
❌ Inflammation of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII):
Incorrect: Inflammation of the eighth cranial nerve causes vestibular neuritis or labyrinthitis. It is thought to be a viral or post-viral inflammatory disorder which leads to inflammation of the vestibular portion of the nerve. Patients often present with severe vertigo and possibly hearing loss and tinnitus. It typically occurs as an acute attack that lasts for days. This patient’s presentation and duration of symptoms favor another diagnosis.  
✅ Debris within the semicircular canal  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Excessive build-up of the endolymph fluid:
Incorrect: Excessive build-up of the endolymph fluid, also known as endolymphatic hydrops, describes the hypothesis behind Ménière disease. The condition is characterized by episodic vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss. It is thought to occur due to an abnormality in the flow of endolymph or in the resorption of endolymph. The increased volume of the endolymph can lead to damage of the cochlea and the vestibular system of the inner ear. This patient’s presentation and intact hearing favor another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man goes to his primary care physician for evaluation of hearing loss. The patient has had progressive bilateral hearing loss for several months, with hearing in the right ear worse than that of the left. He recalls, “I knew something was wrong when I was at a dinner party last week and could not hear my conversation over the other patrons.” He currently works as a band manager for a group of local rock musicians. On physical exam, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 151/83 mmHg, and pulse is 75/min. An otoscopic examination is performed and demonstrates the following (with similar findings on the contralateral side):



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons 

A tuning fork is struck and placed on the patient's forehead, and the patient reports localization of sound to the left ear. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient's clinical condition?

choices.text: Chronic mechanical damage to stereociliated cells in the organ of Corti
Bony overgrowth involving the footplate of the stapes
Age-related changes in hair cells, stria vascularis, and afferent spiral ganglion neurons

questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy patient has asymmetric hearing loss, a normal tympanic membrane, and Weber test consistent with sensorineural hearing loss. Given the patient’s history and occupation, his presentation is consistent with noise-induced hearing loss.

Noise-induced hearing loss is caused by mechanical trauma to stereociliated cells within the cochlea. When the ear is exposed to excessively loud sounds over a prolonged period of time, overstimulation of the inner ear structures results in production of reactive oxygen species, which leads to oxidative cell death. It most commonly occurs in patients with chronic, hazardous sound exposures (e.g., musicians, construction workers).

Clinically, this disorder presents with progressive high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. The hearing loss can be symmetrical or asymmetrical, wherein hearing loss in one ear is more severe than that of the other. Less common associated symptoms include tinnitus or episodic vertigo.  

Option Analysis

✅ Chronic mechanical damage to stereociliated cells in the organ of Corti:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Bony overgrowth involving the footplate of the stapes:
Incorrect: Otosclerosis is characterized by bony remodeling and overgrowth of the middle ear ossicles. The footplate of the stapes is most commonly affected. The condition presents with low-frequency conductive hearing loss. In contrast, this patient’s Weber test finding (i.e. localization to the ear with more mild hearing loss) suggests sensorineural hearing loss.
❌ Traumatic tympanic membrane perforation:
Incorrect: Tympanic membrane perforation may occur in individuals exposed to loud noises (e.g., gunshots, bomb explosions). However, this patient’s tympanic membrane is intact without evidence of perforation.
❌ Impaired reabsorption of endolymphatic fluid:
Incorrect: Meniere disease is characterized by impaired reabsorption and accumulation of endolymphatic fluid within the cochlea and vestibular organs.  The condition typically presents with episodes of unilateral hearing loss associated with tinnitus and vertigo.
❌ Age-related changes in hair cells, stria vascularis, and afferent spiral ganglion neurons:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the pathophysiology of presbycusis. Presbycusis is an age-related condition characterized by bilateral, high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Symptoms of presbycusis generally become noticeable around the age of 60, whereas this patient is only in his 40s.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of difficulty hearing. The patient's partner states “The TV is so loud at home, I can barely hear myself think! I have told him multiple times that he needs hearing aids.” The patient’s past medical history is notable for hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and hyperlipidemia. He is retired but used to work as an accountant. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. An otoscopic examination is performed and reveals the following:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Audiometric screening demonstrates bilateral high-frequency hearing loss. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Age-related changes in hair cells, stria vascularis, and afferent spiral ganglion neurons
Bony overgrowth involving the footplate of the stapes
Benign growth of keratinized squamous epithelium

questions.solution:
This elderly patient has bilateral hearing loss, a normal otoscopic examination, and audiometric testing demonstrating high-frequency hearing loss. These findings are consistent with presbycusis.

Presbycusis is an age-related condition that affects approximately two-thirds of adults over 70. Globally, it is the most common cause of hearing loss. Multiple factors contribute to the disease. However, it is considered primarily a disease of aging of the inner ear structures and is characterized by a loss of cochlear hair cells, stria vascularis cells, and spiral ganglion neurons. These changes result in an inability to effectively convert sound information into neural signals that can be processed by the brain.

Clinically, presbycusis will be seen in elderly patients with progressively worsening bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Patients may describe difficulty hearing and understanding conversations in a crowded or noisy environment. Audiometric testing will demonstrate difficulty hearing high frequency sound (typically those above 2000 Hz). As the disease progresses, middle and lower frequency sounds can be lost as well.    

Option Analysis

✅ Age-related changes in hair cells, stria vascularis, and afferent spiral ganglion neurons:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Bony overgrowth involving the footplate of the stapes:
Incorrect: Otosclerosis reflects bony overgrowth involving the footplate of the stapes, which presents with low-frequency conductive hearing loss with a normal appearing tympanic membrane. Unlike presbycusis, otosclerosis more commonly presents in the 2nd to 3rd decade of life.
❌ Mechanical damage of cochlear structures   :
Incorrect: Noise-induced hearing loss is characterized by mechanical trauma to stereociliated cells within the cochlea. It tends to affect individuals with a history of exposure to loud noises (e.g., musicians, construction workers). In contrast, this patient has no such history.  
❌ Infiltration by polygonal squamous cells :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the histopathology of squamous cell cancer of the ear, which is a rare neoplasm. Physical examination would likely demonstrate associated lymphadenopathy, nerve palsy, and significant ear pain.
❌ Benign growth of keratinized squamous epithelium:
Incorrect: This answer describes the underlying pathophysiology of a cholesteatoma. Cholesteatomas are abnormal, noncancerous accumulations of keratinized squamous epithelium that most commonly develop behind the tympanic membrane. On physical examination, they often appear as a brown, irregular mass. In contrast, this patient has a normal tympanic membrane.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman goes to an urgent care center for evaluation of left ear pain. The patient recently travelled to Las Vegas for a friend's bachelorette party, and upon returning, noticed her ear had become red, itchy, and painful. She also has difficulty hearing out of the left ear. Past medical history is notable for chronic ear infections as a child. The patient takes only birth control pills. Vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination reveals an erythematous ear canal and the presence of yellowish-grey cerumen. The tympanic membrane is mildly erythematous but nondistended. Pain is elicited with manipulation of the pinna. Further discussion with the patient will most likely reveal which of the following historical features?
questions.solution:
This patient has left ear pain, itching, and erythema. The physical examination demonstrates the presence of erythema and cerumen in the external ear canal. These findings are consistent with otitis externa. Additional history is most likely to reveal recent hot tub usage, as water exposure is a known risk factor for the development of this condition.

Otitis externa refers to inflammation of the external auditory canal or auricle. Clinically, it presents with ear pain, pruritus, erythema, and discharge. Patients will often have reproducible pain with pressure or manipulation of the auricle.

The most common infectious cause of otitis externa is Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is primarily a water-borne pathogen. Otitis externa can also be caused by Staphylococcus species and other bacteria, and less commonly by fungi (e.g. Aspergillus) and viruses (e.g. varicella-zoster virus).

The greatest risk factor for developing otitis externa is prolonged exposure to water (e.g., swimming pools, hot tubs), and hence the condition is colloquially termed “swimmer’s ear.” Other risk factors include recent trauma or manipulation of the outer ear, usage of devices such as hearing aids, and skin conditions such as atopic dermatitis and psoriasis that damage the skin’s integrity in the external ear.  

Option Analysis

✅ Recent hot tub usage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Eustachian tube dysfunction:
Incorrect: Eustachian tube dysfunction is a known risk factor for the development of acute otitis media. However, this patient’s physical exam demonstrates erythema as well as cerumen in the external ear canal, which is more consistent with otitis externa.
❌ Application of new sunscreen:
Incorrect: Any new topical exposure to the skin can cause atopic dermatitis, but this condition would likely present with an erythematous pruritic rash without evidence of involvement of the ear canal. In contrast, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with otitis externa.
❌ Recent upper respiratory tract infection  :
Incorrect: A recent upper respiratory tract infection can cause eustachian tube swelling and dysfunction. It can predispose patients to acute otitis media. However, it is not a known risk factor for the development of otitis externa.
❌ Exposure to tobacco smoke:
Incorrect: Exposure to tobacco smoke is a risk factor for the development of acute otitis media, along with air pollution, family history, and age. However, this patient has erythema as well as cerumen in the external ear canal, which is more consistent with otitis externa.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of left ear pain. The patient's mother states, “He has been tugging on his left ear for the past three days; he just cannot seem to get any relief.”  The patient has been taking tylenol at home for symptomatic relief. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for the following finding:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy pediatric patient presents for evaluation of left ear pain, ear tugging, and fever. Otoscopic examination demonstrates a fluid-filled middle ear and bulging tympanic membrane. Given these findings, the patient likely has otitis media, which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Otitis media is an acute bacterial infection of the middle ear and is common in children. Clinical features include ear pain, ear tugging, hearing loss, ear drainage, and low-grade fevers. Otoscopic evaluation of the inner ear is necessary for the diagnosis of acute otitis media, which will most commonly demonstrate a bulging and erythematous tympanic membrane. The tympanic membrane may also have a white or pale yellow color, reflecting the pus accumulating behind the membrane. In rarer cases, patients may have a perforated tympanic membrane with purulent otorrhea.

If left untreated, acute otitis media may progress to acute mastoiditis, infection of the mastoid bone, which can worsen even further to cause central nervous system infections, such as septic thrombosis, subdural empyema, brain abscess, and epidural abscess. Cases of recurrent otitis media may result in conductive hearing loss, due to either ossicular erosion or tympanic membrane perforation.

Option Analysis

✅ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
Incorrect:Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of acute otitis externa and malignant otitis externa. However, this patient has a bulging and fluid-filled tympanic membrane, which is more consistent with the presentation of otitis media.
❌ Moraxella Catarrhalis:
Incorrect: Moraxella Catarrhalis is implicated in the pathogenesis of acute otitis media. However, Streptococcus pneumoniae is a more common cause.  
❌ Candida parapsilosis  :
Incorrect: Candida parapsilosis is a rare cause of malignant otitis externa, which can present with necrosis and granulation tissue in the external auditory canal. In contrast, this patient has a bulging and fluid-filled tympanic membrane, which is more suggestive of otitis media.
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus, like Candida parapsilosis, is associated with malignant otitis externa. However, it is not associated with otitis media.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman goes to the emergency department for evaluation of a painful left ear. She was evaluated one week ago for her symptoms by her primary care physician, who prescribed otic ofloxacin drops. The patient has been taking her medication as prescribed without relief of symptoms and now has worsening discharge from the ear and pain with chewing. Medical history is notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and insulin-dependent diabetes. The patient's temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 168/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals the following finding:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of diabetes mellitus is presenting with otitis externa unresponsive to topical antibiotics. She also meets SIRS criteria and has granulation tissue at the inferior portion of the external auditory canal. These findings are concerning for malignant otitis externa, for which Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause.

Malignant otitis externa refers to a necrotizing infection of the external auditory ear canal that frequently spreads to the base of the skull, causing osteomyelitis and intracerebral infection. This disease is primarily seen in the elderly, individuals with underlying diabetes (particularly advanced diabetes or diabetes that requires insulin treatment), and immunocompromised patients.

Clinically, malignant otitis externa is very difficult to distinguish from simple otitis externa early in the disease process. Key distinguishing features include granulation tissue that is frequently visible in the inferior portion of the external auditory canal, pain with chewing, and exquisite otalgia. The underlying pathogen is most commonly Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which accounts for more than 95% of cases. Staphylococcus aureus and Candida parapsilosis account for the remaining 5% of infections.  

Option Analysis

✅ Pseudomonas aeruginosa  :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Streptococcus pneumoniae :
Incorrect: Streptococcus pneumoniae is more commonly implicated in simple otitis media, which presents with a bulging tympanic membrane and ear pain. Otitis media would not manifest with necrosis or granulation tissue in the external auditory canal.  
❌ Moraxella Catarrhalis:
Incorrect: Moraxella Catarrhalis, like Streptococcus Pneumoniae, is more commonly implicated in simple otitis media. 
❌ Candida parapsilosis:
Incorrect: Candida parapsilosis is associated with malignant otitis externa. However, it is overall a much less common cause. 95% of cases of malignant otitis externa are due to Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus, like Candida parapsilosis, is associated with malignant otitis externa. However, Pseudomonas aeruginosa is still by far the most common cause of malignant otitis externa.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to sudden onset of a spinning sensation accompanied by instability and nausea for the past 2 days. She had a cold one week ago that resolved spontaneously. Since the symptoms have started, she has vomited 3 times. Medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes per day for the last 25 years. The patient appears to be in distress. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination reveals mild hearing loss in the right ear. The patient is given a medication that is known to affect the vestibular end-organ receptors to control her symptoms. The physician advises the patient to not use the medication while driving because drowsiness is a potential side effect. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the medication prescribed by the physician?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with acute onset of vertigo, hearing loss, nausea, and vomiting following a viral infection, most likely has the peripheral vertigo associated with vestibular neuritis or labyrinthitis. Vestibular neuritis refers to the post-viral inflammatory disorder of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII).  

Regardless of the etiology, vertigo is treated symptomatically, and disease-specific treatment is added depending on the etiology. Symptomatic treatment of vertigo includes 3 drug classes: antihistamines (e.g., meclizine, diphenhydramine), antiemetics (e.g., ondansetron, metoclopramide), and benzodiazepines (e.g., diazepam, lorazepam). The latter is rarely used due to the serious side effect profile. Antihistamines are the drugs of choice in most cases.  

Antihistamines work by blocking the H1 histamine receptor, which suppresses vestibular end-organ receptors and inhibits activation of central cholinergic pathways. Antihistamines can cause drowsiness, and patients should be advised to not use this medication prior to activities that require focus.  

Option Analysis

❌ Antagonism of 5-HT3 serotonin receptors:
Incorrect: 5-HT3 antagonism is the mechanism of action of ondansetron, a powerful central-acting antiemetic. This medication blocks serotonin receptors both centrally, in the chemoreceptor trigger zone, and peripherally, on vagal nerve terminals. It is used to prevent vomiting in post-operative patients and in patients undergoing cancer chemotherapy. It can be used to treat nausea in the setting of vertigo, but it would not cause drowsiness.  
❌ Antagonism of D2 dopamine receptors:
Incorrect: Antagonism of D2 dopamine receptors is the mechanism of action of metoclopramide. This medication blocks dopamine receptors in the chemoreceptor trigger zone of the CNS. It enhances motility and gastric emptying, and it increases lower esophageal sphincter tone. Uses include diabetic and postoperative gastroparesis, antiemetic, and persistent GERD. It can be used to treat nausea in the setting of vertigo, but it would not cause drowsiness.  
✅ Antagonism of H1 histamine receptor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Antagonism of the neurokinin-1 Receptor :
Incorrect: Aprepitant prevents vomiting by inhibiting the substance P/neurokinin 1 (NK1) receptor in the area postrema. This medication is mainly used for chemotherapy-induced emesis. It is not used as a treatment for vertigo.  
❌ Antagonism of muscarinic receptors  :
Incorrect: Antagonism of muscarinic receptors is the mechanism of action of scopolamine. This medication is used for prevention of nausea/vomiting associated with motion sickness, recovery from anesthesia and surgery. However, it is not used as a treatment for vertigo.
